Allan Donald is a former South African cricketer who played as a fast bowler for the South African national team and several domestic teams. He was one of the most successful fast bowlers in the history of cricket, and is often considered one of the greatest cricketers of all time.

Donald made his debut for the South African national team in 1992 and quickly became a key player for the team. He was known for his speed, aggression, and accuracy, and became one of the most feared fast bowlers in the world. He played in 72 Test matches and took 330 wickets, making him the second highest wicket-taker in the history of the format. He also played in 164 One Day Internationals and took 272 wickets, making him the highest wicket-taker in the history of the format for his country.

Donald was also a key player for several domestic teams, including Natal and Transvaal. He was known for his fierce competitiveness and determination, and was known for physically intimidating batsmen. He was a key player in the South African team that won the 1992 World Cup, and was also part of the team that won the 1998 Commonwealth Games.

Donald retired from international cricket in 2003, but continued to play domestic cricket until 2008. He is now a cricket commentator and analyst, and is also involved in charitable work in South Africa.
